speakeroldname: Mr. Charles A. Langlois (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Industry, Science and Technology):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to offer some brief comments on the comments just made by the hon. member for Western Arctic.
I would like to point out to her that I share her concerns about the airline situation in this country and specifically the Canadian Airlines situation.
I would like to tell her that it is not the participation of the employees, or the project for the employees to participate in the survival of the company that creates some problems. On the contrary. It should and it would help the situation. It is the other part of the financial package that is being put together that causes some concern to the government and that the government is really looking at.
Also, I would like to offer to her that even without Bill C-327, it would not prevent the employees of Canadian Airlines from participating in their company. I would like to share some comments I have and some concerns I have with the House and with my hon. colleagues on Bill C-327.

As the hon. members know, Bill C-327 recommends that government encourage employees to take an economic interest in the corporation that employs them.
This motion-and let us not forget it-would amend the Income Thx Act to allow for a deduction from taxable income for 50 percent of the employee's and employer's net investment in an employee share purchase program, as well as the interest earned by a financial institution on loans to such plans.
To qualify for these tax preferences, the employees have to take over the employing corporation. But first, I would like to thank the hon. member for raising the issue of improved employer-employee relations. It is a well-known fact that work relations improve when employee participation in the corporation increases.
Government recognizes that co-operation between the two groups improves Canadian businesses competitiveness and thus the growth of our economy in the long term.
As hon. members probably know, in 1984 the previous government proposed in a publication entitled "Gain Sharing for A Stronger Economy" a plan which would have provided, for the payment of employees, a tax credit shared between employers and employees according to a percentage of the profits.
As with most employee ownership plans, the objectives of that one were to improve labour-management relations and to increase labour productivity.
You will also recall, Mr. Speaker, that labour and management groups were against that proposal. After a careful examination, the government of the day rejected it.
This is not at all surprising, considering the objectives that the government pursued subsequently with its tax reform. One of those main objectives was to promote decisions what could stimulate the economy instead of giving particular tax incentives. That objective was at-
November 20, 1992

tained by the elimination of many incentives which, often, were open to only a small group of taxpayers.
Also many deductions were eliminated or replaced with credits. Then the broadening of the tax base had the effect of reducing tax rates. Thus many Canadians, mostly older people or low income people, had their tax liability reduced.
Bill C-327 will defeat that objective because it would effectively promote the use of public funds to the benefit of a small group of individuals who want to take control of the business that employs them.
Considering the importance of controlling the deficit, it would become necessary to increase taxes of all other Canadians in order to support the employee share ownership plans. In that respect it is important that hon. members realize that what Bill C-327 proposes is, to some extent, a redistribution of income.
But more important, the tax reform greatly helped to reduce tax incentives which had the effect of distorting the economic decision-making process. The broadening of the tax base and the reduction of tax rates, by helping to eliminate the incentives which distorted investment decisions, promoted long-term economic growth.
Moreover not only are these initial deductions distorting economic decisions, but the national and international experience shows that a large part of these tax incentives is given to people for something they would have done anyway. Therefore we are using considerable revenues to encourage a minimal additional activity.
At a time when government is trying to use wisely its scarce resources, it does not seem to me appropriate to implement such a plan. As hon. members know, interest on the federal debt will amount to $43.2 billion this year, that is 27 cents per dollar of budgetary expenditures.
Every dollar added today to the deficit increases the debt burden of future generations. It is therefore very important that we reduce the debt. We will succeed only by controlling expenses and protecting fiscal revenues.
The impact of Bill C-327 on the deficit would be significant as the generous fiscal treatment could encourage a large number of companies to restructure the

remuneration of employees in such a way as to take maximum advantage of the incentive.
In some cases, financial participation of employees in their company can increase productivity and therefore stimulate the general economy. This is why our fiscal system already encourages such measures. In particular, the government is strongly backing the financial participation of employees through labour sponsored venture capital corporations. The preferential treatment given these corporations has been further improved in the last budget. Employees are also benefiting from special privileges when they are given options to buy shares by their employer.
Combined with the generous lifetime capital gains exemption, these programs are a powerful incentive to employees to buy shares in Canadian companies without distorting on investment decisions.
As we said during the last budget, the government would rather rely on the strong principles underlying the labour sponsored venture capital corporations which are prohibited from investing in a single company. This provision is based on the old adage which advises not to put all the eggs in one basket. In the case of the proposal of Bill C-327 the eggs are not only the worker's investments. They are also his job.
I believe hon. members will agree with me that it would be inappropriate for the government to encourage individuals to take such risks.
I think I speak for a large number of Canadians when I say that increased productivity and better labour relations are key elements to the success of our great country. However, I fear that Bill C-327 will not help in that matter. Not only will it be costly and unfair but also it might not achieve what it was meant for.
I thank you, Mr. Speaker, for the opportunity to deal with this issue in this House. I hope my hon. colleagues will find the information I gave them useful in judging the merits of Bill C-327.

It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise today to speak on Bill C-327, presented by my NDP colleague from Sault Ste. Marie.

This bill has come at the right time. It is a private member's bill which speaks to the problem that employees have in buying into a company which many times may be in difficulty and the employees want to actually save the company.
I should bring to the House's attention that this is not a rare occurrence. There is legislation which in effect permits employees to buy into a company and actually become the owners of a company. I can give you the example of Weirton Steel in Ohio which was to be closed in 1982 because, of course, of low profits-remember the 1982 recession. The employees decided to buy into the company and actually purchased the plant entirely. Finally what they succeeded in doing was turning that company around, and that meant that the owners of the company reaped the benefits of having turned it around after it was about ready to go into bankruptcy.
But something closer to us, in Kapuskasing, Ontario there was a recent success in an employee buy out, where Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company reported a $2 million profit between December 1, 1991 and June 30, 1992. Before that time, before the employees had bought it out, it was in a deficit position.
It makes me think that perhaps we should have the employees buy out this government. Maybe we would have the country finally running in a profit-making position. I do not know, but maybe that is called an election. Maybe the federal example for an employee buy out is an election. In any case, in other jurisdictions employee buy outs have been very successful,making it easy for employees to buy a company is nothing new. We have had that in Quebec for a long time now thanks to a piece of legislation called the Co-operatives Act which allows employees to buy a company, whether it is in financial trouble or not.

I feel that the idea behind this private member's bill presented by my colleague from the NDP makes a lot of sense. I think that my friend opposite does understand what I mean by that. It makes a lot of sense to let employees buy a company if they so desire and to make it easier for them to do so. That is exactly what Bill C-327 is all about.
I would like to draw the Chair's attention to the fact that this common sense approach could be applied to the airline industry. However, this bill is no panacea. We must not kid ourselves and believe that employees working for airlines such as Canadian Air or Air Canada will be able to buy those companies. It is too much money, it is impossible. For my part, I think that as a government we must be extremely cautious before even considering giving one penny to either Canadian Air or Air Canada. We have to be cautious because I am convinced that giving money away, $300 million here, $300 million there, will end up being a disservice to Canadians. Therefore, in that respect I am extremely conservative, and I must apologize for using this term. I am not sure I would be prepared to invest taxpayers' money to take an active interest in an airline.

tions because it came too late in French and they were not familiar with the French terms.
I do like what the government has done this time. The government report said we will use common sense and if we need to have the English translated into French we will have a French person in that district decide whether it is really practical. Mr. Speaker, I think the NDP member should be congratulated because this is a common sense measure, legislation encouraging employees to buy shares in their employer's company. The reason I want to say a few words on this is that I had the honour to represent the Papineau riding at the provincial level and I developed an interest for this kind of program allowing employees to buy the company they were working for, for whatever reason. I remember, at that time, asking the American Embassy for information because the U.S. had implemented similar legislation. Their plan was called ESOP, the Employee Share Ownership Plan. According to the bill adopted by the American Congress, employees could invest in their company enough to acquire a majority of the shares and the government helped the employees buy the company. Therefore, it is a very logical, down to earth measure. In the U.S., they called the results of the ESOP program:
Private Members' Business
"People's Capitalism". It is people's capitalism if you wish; it is very simple. Employees have the opportunity, with the help of the government, to buy a company either because it is having a hard time or because it is about to close down; whatever the reason, employees can buy the shares.
The advantage of all this is that after two years, the American Senate requested a report on that program; after all, the government did invest millions of dollars.
Much to their surprise, they realized the productivity in employee owned companies increased, not only by 10, 15 or 20 per cent, but even by 150 per cent in some cases. That goes to show that when employees can influence company policies and implement measures to increase productivity it works. Why? It is all very simple. When you own the company, when your input or your contribution will show up on you pay cheque then you will certainly do everything you can to increase productivity.
I wonder why such a bill was not introduced before. I think we made a step in the right direction by doing so today. We know miracles never happen in this House. We come up with projects and ideas, and it all takes time. Our friends on the other side, they are few and there will be fewer in the future, do not realize that is the way to go. If people are ready to invest in their own future, I think we will get extraordinary results. The timing is excellent and I think this bill will be studied in committee. The government may not be ready for such measures, but I know one thing: whatever the future holds for us, people want to contribute to the prosperity of our country. The best way to prosper is to have a vested interest in success, and to profit from it. This bill makes a lot of sense. It is very sensible and its time has come.
I just want to add that it has been tried in the United States. I have some results here. Yes, I have, I asked the American embassy for documentation a few years back. We can see how successful it was in the States, and I know we can achieve the same results, if not better, here.
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank you for the few minutes you gave me. I hope this bill is a good start, that one day it will become reality and play a major part in rebuilding our economy.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the words of the member for Papineau and my colleague from Chambly. I must extend my thanks to the government side as well for allowing this bill to go forward at second reading to a legislative committee. It is very personally gratifying to have that co-operation among the three parties. As we all know we do not see it too often. Therefore, I do appreciate the co-operation from the two other parties and of course from my own colleagues.
As the member indicated, this is a concept that is not new. It is very much alive in the United States and in Europe. Its time has come. Of course our perspective on this is that Bill C-327 employee ownership is social democracy in action. Some people say that social democracy is dead and we say it is not. This is one way that we can show in a very positive way that employees, employers and governments can participate and effect change in the workplace.
Bill C-327 was brought about because of the Algoma Steel Corporation. We went through a great deal of distress in the community and there was some urgency. There was a crisis, that the entire company would close and many thousands of people would be put out of work. However, again co-operation from the Ontario government and federal government spearheaded by the union and sacrifice on the part of the workers brought about an employee majority ownership of the corporation.
I want to say that the Algoma Steel situation prompted the bringing forward of this bill. Since that time the model of this bill could be used in a whole host of other cases.
I think legislation is necessary to treat the potential closings of industries and large and small businesses across this country. Rather than governments having to deal with them on a piecemeal basis, on a one-by-one basis in a crisis situation in a day-to-day situation, it is imperative that we deal with it in a logical, comprehensive way and I think this legislation is a start.
I am very much accepting of the fact that when it does go to committee, amendments may in fact be in order. This bill deals with majority ownership, but I think it is imperative that partial ownership be recognized. Maybe that is the route to go.
I look forward to what will happen at committee that I understand has to be struck within five days. I look forward to some expediency in this matter because each and every day there are new considerations by new people, new businesses or businesses that are in difficulty-
I cite the Balmer mine in British Columbia that presently is undergoing this consideration. There is a company called Rexdale in Haileybury in northern Ontario where the process failed because there was no legislation in place.
I think the time has come to thank people from across the country, both individuals who have signed petitions and people who have given quite good support from across the country, so there is widespread support for the concept if not the specific bill.
We have had petitions in from Newfoundland, St. John's and Mount Pearl; in Ontario, Sault Ste. Marie, St. Thomas, Brampton, Keewatin, Thunder Bay, Ottawa, Kemptville, Wawa, Kenora, London, Longbow Lake, Nepean, Stratford, Clarence Creek; in Quebec, Val-des-Monts, Gatineau, Aylmer; Regina, Saskatchewan; in B.C., Chilliwack, Sardis, Port Albemi, Nanaimo, Vedder Crossing, Cultus Lake; in the Northwest Territories, Yellowknife.
There is, indeed, widespread support. As far as business goes, the Chamber of Commerce in my city supports it. The Algoma Steel Credit Union, in labour CUPE local 5; Hamilton, Transportation and Communi-. cations Union of CLC; Port Albemi and District Labour Council; St. Thomas and District Labour Council; the city of Sault Ste. Marie; Saskatchewan Economic Diversification and Trade; Saskatchewan Minister of Labour and the British Columbia Labour and Consumer Services under the signature of Moe Sihota, support it.
There is indication that the country and the residents of the country are prepared to address this. Once again I want to thank the government for allowing this bill to go forward to committee in the very near future.
